722828f-c.text:
Riverside Drive (thoroughfare in the foreground, extending from right to left margins), at West 165th Street (intersection at the right) and viewing northeastward towards the Columbia University Presbyterian Hospital Center. The photographers vantage point is in the park area on the west side of the Drive.opposite the New York Institution for the Deaf which does not appear in these (3) views. This medical center occupies the land east of the Drive, between same and Broadway, from
West 165th north to 168th Street.
May 23, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

715743f-a.text:
165th Street, east from and including Riverside Drive. In the upper left hand corner is the Presbyterian Hospital, a part of
the great Medical Center.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722831f.text:
Riverside Drive (buildings fronting thereon), south from about West 172nd (left) to 160th (right) Streets, showing in the center, thereon the old buildings of the New York Institution for the Deaf. The ImOdern structures to the north of same are units of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. In the foreground is the southern portion of Fort Washington Park with a court and club (building, left foreground) therein. Paralleling the North River edge are the tracks of the New York Central Railroad. The photographers vantage point is the new George Washington
Bridge and he is viewing in a southeastward direction.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway.

722829f-a.text:
Riverside Drive (foreground) east side, at West 165th Street and viewing northeastward across grounds and units of Columbia UniversityPresbyterian Medical Center. Note under construction, the Service
Building.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722833f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, east side, north from West 165th Street (left) showing the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing, a unit of the Columbia University-Presbyterian Medical Center. No 2 of this set of 2 views shows the southern side of same as viewed northward from Wost
165th Street between the Drive and Washington Ave.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722833f-b.text:
Riverside Drive, east side, north from West 165th Street (left) showing the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing, a unit of the Columbia University-Presbyterian Medical Center. No 2 of this set of 2 views shows the southern side of same as viewed northward from Wost
165th Street between the Drive and Washington Ave.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722834f-b.text:
Riverside Drive, north from West 165th Street and showing that area between same and the North (Hudson) River being landscaped as a part of the Park Department's West Side Improvement Project. Note the new George Washington Bridge at West 181st Street and a grassy plot under same, that was formerly known as Fort Washington Park and which will lose its identity upon the completion of this combined Municipal and railroad project. This set consists of 3 views, Nos. 2 and 3 of which are photographed at West 167th Street.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722834f-c.text:

715742f-a.text:
0ld School for Deaf, s.e. corner of 155h St. & Riverside Dr.
Au0. 21, 1939
P.L. Sperr, photographer

722830f-a.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, at the S.E. corner of West 165th Street, showing a corner of the grounds and buildings of the New York Institution for the Deaf. On the left is a view eastward on the south side of 165th Street across Fort Washington Ave., to Broadway.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view solely of the Riverside Drive frontage.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722832f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, north across W. 165th Street. At that point the grounds of the Columbia Medical Center begin. The Presbyterian Hospital of Nursing of same is repeated in two of these items. The main buildings are detailed in the third. The latter nestle around
Broadway at 168th Street.
View 1: August 21, 1939
View 2: June 18, 1940
View 3: May 18, 1940
P. L. Sperr

722835f-a.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, north from West 165th Street and showing upon the east side of same,units of Columbia University-Presbyterian Medical Center. They are from right to left, the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing (partially shown), the New York State
Psychiatric Institute . and Hospital, and Bard Hall.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The entrance from the Drive between the New York State Psychiatric Instituteon (left) and the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing (right). At the rear of the first mentioned unit is a similar structure,
the Neurological Institute.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A southward view emphasi2ing the New York State Psychiatric Institute as viewed from a point slightly north of West 168th Street. To the left of the aforementioned building is the Neurological
Institute.
October 5, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
